chapter.title: Review of common LD descriptors
chapter.content:
Review of common LD descriptors

This module examined current trends and issues in defining LD. We started by examining the language we use to describe individuals with learning challenges. As a reminder, some of these descriptors include:

  • Learning differences
  • Learning difficulties
  • Learning challenges
  • Learning disorders

Two guiding questions helped to clarify what it means to have LD as opposed to a learning difficulty, difference, or challenge. Click the forward arrow to review our two guiding questions.

chapter.title: Review of guiding question #1
chapter.content:
Review of guiding question #1

Guiding question number one asked:

What are six consensus statements that help us understand the definition of LD?

To address this question we examined six consensus statements:

  1. The concept of LD is valid and is supported by strong converging evidence.
  2. LD are neurologically based and intrinsic to the individual.
  3. Individuals with LD show intra-individual differences in skills and abilities.
  4. LD persist across the life span.
  5. LD may occur in combination with other disabling conditions, but they are not due to other conditions.
  6. LD are evident across ethnic, cultural, language, and economic groups.

These six consensus statements are important because they represent what is agreed upon in the field of LD.

chapter.title: Review of guiding question #2
chapter.content:
Review of guiding question #2

Guiding question number two asked:

What are examples from your work with adults with LD that are associated with the six consensus statements?

This question led us to explore your experiences in order to help make the definition of LD more meaningful.

We also explored two models for diagnosing individuals as having LD that are currently allowable by federal special education legislation:

  • IQ-Achievement discrepancy model
  • Response to Intervention (RtI) model

Click the forward arrow to share your reflections about what you learned in this module.

chapter.title: Activity: Share your thoughts about the concepts and ideas presented in Definitions of Learning Disabilities
chapter.content:
Activity: Share your thoughts about the concepts and ideas presented in Definitions of Learning Disabilities

To wrap up, please take a moment to review the working definition of LD that you wrote at the beginning of this module, as well as your previous thoughts on how the six consensus statements may affect your work with adults having diagnosed or undiagnosed LD.

Then, reflect on what you have learned and how you plan to use the information in your work with adults by answering the following questions:

  1. What additional insight do you now have about what it means for an individual to have LD?
  2. How might the information you learned in this module affect your work with adults?

Please share your reflections in the LINCS Disabilities in Adult Education Group before moving on.

When you have finished posting your reflections, click the forward arrow to continue.

chapter.title: Participate in the forum discussions
chapter.content:
Participate in the forum discussions

Congratulations on completing Learning to Achieve’s Definitions of Learning Disabilities! We encourage you to stay involved in the LINCS Community and the LINCS Disabilities in Adult Education Group as you strive to identify and understand LD. We encourage you to discuss and apply your newly acquired knowledge and learn about others' experiences in teaching adults with LD.
